variant.question: An aircraft operating within airspace Class G, under VFR and above 10 000 ft shall maintain a distance from clouds of at least

options.text: 1 500 m horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of at least 8 km.
1 NM horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of at least 5 km.
1 500 m horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of at least 5 km.
1 NM horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of at least 8 km.

variant.question: Flights operating within airspace classified as G above an altitude of 10 000 ft MSL and in accordance with VFR shall observe the following weather minima

options.text: a distance from cloud: 1 500 m horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 8 km.
a distance from cloud: 1 Nautical Mile (NM) horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 5 km.
a distance from cloud: 1 500 m horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 5 km.
a distance from cloud: 1 Nautical Mile (NM) horizontally, 1 000 ft vertically; flight visibility: 8 km.

variant.question: The standard Vertical Separation Minimum (VSM) between flights operating in accordance with IFR, within controlled airspace, below FL290 is
Under normal circumstances, except for Class A airspace, what is the minimum distance from clouds and minimum visibility for a VFR flight operated above the transition altitude and below FL100

options.text: 1500 metres horizontally, 300 metres vertically and 5 kilometres.
1500 metres horizontally, 300 metres vertically and 8 kilometres.
1500 metres horizontally, 1000 metres vertically and 5 kilometres.
1000 metres horizontally, 1500 metres vertically and 8 kilometres.

variant.question: What are the cloud clearance and visibility requirements in class B airspace, below 10 000 ft?

options.text: 1.5 km horizontal distance, 1 000 ft vertical distance, 5 km visibility.
1.5 km horizontal distance, 1 000 ft vertical distance, 8 km visibility.

variant.question: Choose 3 lateral separation methods

According to the Standardised European Rules of the Air, what shall be the distance from clouds when an aircraft flies under VFR in the following conditions:Airspace: Class G 
 Aircraft altitude: 3500 ft AMSL 
 Terrain elevation: 2800 ft AMSL

options.text: Clear of clouds and with the surface in sight.

variant.question: When an aircraft is operating in class F airspace below 900 m AMSL, the minimum horizontal distance from cloud for VFR flight is:

options.text: clear of clouds and in sight of the surface.

variant.question: The vertical separation minimum for RVSM-approved aircraft flying in the same direction, on the same route, at or above FL290 in RVSM airspace is?
Who is responsible for the development of the contingency procedures required to cover the case of engine failure during an instrument departure, which occurs after V1?

options.text: ATC will provide radar vector for obstacle clearance.
The pilot in close co-operation with ATC.
The designer of the procedure (normally the State).

variant.question: The separation method whereby the vertical and horizontal separation may be reduced to half of the standard value is called

You receive the following clearance: “Cleared to FL100, VDR 6V
departure...

options.text: You have to climb to FL100, and follow all the vertical, lateral, speed restrictions and procedures of the SID
You may climb to FL100, and follow all the vertical, lateral, speed restrictions and Procedures of the SID
You are cleared to climb to FL100, and may follow the vertical,lateral, speed restrictions and procedures of the SID
You are cleared to climb to FL100, and you must follow the speed restrictions of the SID. You may follow the vertical and lateral restrictions of the SID

variant.question: An aircraft operating under VFR, at altitudes between 4500 ft and 9000 ft AMSL, and outside controlled airspace, shall maintain a distance from clouds and a flight visibility of at least..

options.text: 1500 m horizontally and 1000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of 5 km.
600 m horizontally and 1000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of 5 km.
1500 m horizontally and 1000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of 8 km.
1000 m horizontally and 1000 ft vertically, and a flight visibility of 5 km.

variant.question:
An aircraft using on-track DME may be cleared to climb or descend to (or through) the level occupied by another aircraft flying along the same track but in the opposite direction
After it has been positively established that the aircraft have passed each other the longitudinal separation minima applicable in this case are
Above Flight Level (FL) 290 the standard Vertical Separation Minimum (VSM) shall be:
What is the minimum ceiling for a special VFR clearance to be issued?

You are outside controlled airspace on a VFR flight above 3 000 ft
Your distance from the cloud should be

options.text: clear of cloud and in sight of the surface.

variant.question: The standard minimum radar separation provided between aircraft established on the same localiser course (plus additional longitudinal separation as required for wake turbulence) shall be

The absolute (when certain safety related conditions are met) minimum radar separation provided between aircraft established on the same localizer course within 10 NM of the runway shall be(plus additional longitudinal separation as required for wake turbulence)
Separation methods and minima - Vertical Separation Minima (VSM) acc. DOC 4444: Above flight level FL 290 the Vertical Separation Minimum (VSM) for aircraft flying in the same direction shall be :
Above FL290 the standard Vertical Separation Minimum (VSM) for aircraft flying in the same direction shall be:

Longitudinal separation minima based on distance using DME for aircraft at the same cruising level and track, provided that each aircraft utilizes on Track DME stations and separation is checked by obtaining simultaneous DME readings at
For an ASR, within 40 nm of the radar, fix tolerance is assumed to be:
In RVSM airspace, what is the maximum permitted tolerance for a Mode C check?
ICAO specifications are that range errors indicated by Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) should not exceed:

options.text: ±0.25 NM plus 1.25% of the distance measured.
±0.25 NM plus 3% of the distance measured up to a maximum of 5 NM.
±0.5 NM or 3% of the distance measured whichever is the greater.
±1.25 NM plus 0.25% of the distance measured.

variant.question: Aircraft A and B approach each other on converging courses in VMC at approximately the same level in controlled airspace Class D Given that aircraft A is flying under IFR and aircraft B is flying under VFR, which aircraft has the right of way?

options.text: Aircraft B providing it has aircraft A on its left.
Aircraft A regardless of the direction from which aircraft B is approaching.
Aircraft B regardless of the direction from which aircraft A is approaching.
Aircraft A providing it has aircraft B on its right.

variant.question: Which of the following correctly defines aerodrome operating minima?

options.text: Cloud ceiling and RVR for takeoff
Cloud ceiling and ground visibility for takeoff
Cloud base and RVR for takeoff
Cloud base and ground visibility for takeoff

variant.question: A fix of an object measured from a DME has a tolerance of (1) _____, plus (2) _____ the distance to the antenna.
The “Mach number technique” may be applied by ATC to aircraft along the same route in order to...

options.text: reduce the fuel burn in the cruise.
adjust the Mach number as the aircraft`s mass reduces.

variant.question: ATC is using primary surveillance radar, the pilot can expect that the aircraft will be identified on departure ____ from the end of the runway.
Describe how lateral separation of aircraft at the same level may be obtained. By: - Visual observation - VOR, DME - RNAV equipment - RNAV equipment for separations of at least 3 NM
Above FL290 the vertical separation between aircraft on reciprocal tracks will be:

options.text: 1 000 ft within RVSM airspace, 2 000 ft within all other airspace.

variant.question: The longitudinal separation based on time, between aircraft using the same cruising level, may be reduced, provided..

options.text: navigation aids permit frequent determination of the aircraft position and the true airspeed of the preceding aircraft is faster than the following aircraft by at least 20 kt.
navigation aids permit frequent determination of the aircraft position and both aircraft are using Area Navigation techniques.
the two aircraft are flying in VMC and the true airspeed of the preceding aircraft is faster than the following aircraft by at least 20 kt.
the two aircraft are flying in VMC and the two aircraft can maintain two way radio contact with each other.

variant.question: For an aerodrome in Controlled Airspace Class C, ATC provides separation

options.text: between flights under IFR and between IFR and VFR flights, but does not provide separation between flights under VFR.
at aerodromes for arriving traffic, but not for departing traffic.
between flights under IFR, but does not provide separation between IFR and VFR flights, and flights under VFR.
between all flights under IFR and VFR.

variant.question: During an arrival procedure under an IFR flight plan in VMC in airspace class D, traffic avoidance is the responsibility of:
What is the vertical separation minimum between FL290 and FL410 in RVSM airspace?
A VFR flight has been given a clearance by ATC subject to maintaining own separation from other traffic. What or who is responsible for ensuring its separation from other aircraft?

options.text: The pilot of the VFR flight.
The ATC unit controlling the flight.
Clearances to maintain own separation are prohibited.

variant.question: The separation methods applied by ATC for controlled traffic are...
Geographical separation is obtained:

options.text: where aircraft report overhead different geographical locations.
where aircraft are vectored by the controller.
where aircraft maintain separation by visual observation only.

variant.question: When radar capabilities at a given location so permit, the minimum radar separation of 5 NM may be reduced, but shall not be less than:
ATC tells you to “report when runway vacated”. What do you do?

options.text: Vertical separation is obtained by requiring aircraft using prescribed altimeter setting procedures to operate at different levels expressed in terms of flight levels or altitudes.
Vertical separation is obtained by requiring aircraft using prescribed altimeter setting procedures to operate at different levels expressed in terms of flight levels only.
Vertical separation is obtained by requiring aircraft using prescribed altimeter setting procedures to operate at different levels expressed in altitudes only.

Vertical separation is obtained by requiring aircraft using prescribed altimeter setting procedures or GNSS input parameters to operate at different levels expressed in terms of flight levels or altitudes.

variant.question: Horizontal separation is achieved in terms of longitudinal and lateral separation methods. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Longitudinal by time, lateral by different routes.
Longitudinal by different geographical areas, lateral by different routes.
Longitudinal by distance, lateral by time.
Longitudinal by time, lateral by time.

variant.question: Unless otherwise prescribed by the appropriate ATS authority, the horizontal radar separation minimum shall be;

Two aircraft are flying at the same level, one on radial 010º outbound and another on radial 030º outbound are at 15 NM from the nav-aid. What nav-aid must it be, if the aircraft are sufficiently separated?
When in RVSM airspace between FL290 and FL410 the vertical separation between aircraft travelling in opposite directions is:
What is the term called when horizontal and vertical separation is applied?
When operating under Special VFR clearance, the responsibility for remaining clear of obstacles on the ground rests with:

options.text: both the ATC and the pilot-in-command.

variant.question: The minimum radar separation to be provided to aircraft established on the localizer course shall be:

options.text: when experiencing severe icing or turbulence.
when the destination ETA changes by plus or minus 10 minutes.
in case an unruly passenger is identified to be on board.

variant.question: When the Mach number technique (MNT) is being applied, and the preceding aircraft shall maintain a Mach number equal to or greater than the following aircraft an RNAV distance based separation minimum may be used on the same direction tracks in lieu of 10 minutes longitudinal separation minimum. The distance is:
What is the required lateral separation between two aeroplanes which are both using the same navigational aid?

options.text: Lateral angle/distance according to the navigational aid in use.
Different courses of more than 15º and 10 NM of lateral distance.
Different courses of 45º and 10 NM of lateral distance.
Different courses of more than 25º and 15 NM of lateral distance.

variant.question: Track separation between aircraft using the same NDB shall be applied requiring the aircraft to fly:

options.text: at least 30° separated at a distance of 15 NM or more from the facility.
at least 45° separated at a distance of 15 NM or more from the facility.
at least 30° separated at a distance of 15 miles or more from the facility.
at least 15° separated at a distance of 15 NM or more from the facility.

variant.question: Consider ICAO Doc 4444 on lateral separation. Track separation by the use of the same navigation aid requires aircraft to fly on specified tracks.

options.text: which are separated by a minimum amount appropriate to the navigation aid employed.
using visual observation so that aircraft are laterally separated by at least 10 NM.
so that both aircraft are established on tracks to or from the NDB which are diverging by at least 15 degrees and at least one aircraft is at a distance of 10 NM or more from the facility.
so that both aircraft are established on VOR radials diverging by at least 25 degrees and at least one aircraft is at a distance of 5 NM or more from the navigation aid.

variant.question: Aircraft flying along the same track may be separated by DME-distances from the same DME and it is confirmed that the aircraft have passed each other. Specify the shortest difference in DME-distance to make it possible for one aircraft to climb or descend?
How is vertical separation obtained?
For independent parallel approaches, what is the minimum radar separation that is required until the aircraft is established inbound on the ILS localiser course and/or MLS final approach track?
What is correct about class C airspace?

options.text: Separation between IFR traffic and between IFR-VFR traffic but no separation between VFR traffic.
Separation provided to all VFR-VFR and IFR-IFR traffic.
Separation between IFR traffic but no separation between IFR-VFR.
Separation provided to all VFR and IFR traffic.

variant.question: For an operation in NAT HLA airspace where 50 NM lateral separation is used, what is the least accurate RNP specification available?
Where two aircraft are established on the same ILS localizer, what is the minimum radar separation permitted under mode 2 operations (Dependent Parallel Approaches)?

An aircraft is flying towards a major aerodrome and is part of a traffic flow of aircraft operating on the same ATS route, towards the same aerodrome. The pilots expect ATC to assign them, and other aircraft that are part of this traffic flow, cruising levels which will, as far as practicable:

options.text: Have a vertical separation of 1000 ft, when operating within RVSM airspace.
Be separated by at least 500 ft, depending on traffic levels.
Be correct for an approach sequence at the destination.
Have a vertical separation of 1000 ft, when operating below RVSM airspace.

variant.question:
An aircraft is hijacked and is NOT in contact with ATC. No applicable regional procedures have been established. 
 According to ICAO Annex 2. The pilot should try to climb or descend by (1)__ in an area where a vertical separation minimum of (2)__ is applied.
What is meant by the term 'security control' when referring to (EC) No 300/**2008**) or ICAO Annex 17?

options.text: Security control means the application of means by which the introduction of prohibited articles may be prevented.
Security control means the application of means by which the entry of unauthorised persons or unauthorised vehicles, or both, may be prevented.
Security control means the application of technical or other means which are intended to identify and/or detect prohibited articles;
Security control an examination of the implementation of relevant national civil aviation security programme requirements by an airline, airport, or other entity involved in security.
